October 18, 1963

Mr. & Mrs. R.H. Lister,
Box 366, Pelly, Sask.

Dear Mr. & Mrs. Lister:

I wish to acknowledge with thanks the receipt by the Archives of the completed questionnaire. We are pleased to have this record for permanent preservation as a part of the history of this province.

The autobiographical account and histories you mention, Mrs. Lister, would be most acceptable. Records of this type are always a welcome addition to the Archives of this province. We would be pleased to have the opportunity to borrow them for copying or, if you are willing, to keep the originals for permanent preservation. I am trying to arrange to make a trip to your district before the end of this month. If I am able to make the trip I would welcome the opportunity to call on you and perhaps at that time arrange to borrow the records you mentioned. If, however, I am unable to make the trip I would be pleased to have you mail the records to this office. I will advise you as soon as I am able to make a decision on whether or not I can make the trip over to Pelly.

Thank you once again for the trouble you have taken in completing the questionnaire for us and for your offer of additional material.

Yours sincerely,

D.H. Bocking
Assistant Provincial Archivist

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below.

Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires

- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Fortitude in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
SASKATOON, Saskatchewan.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing or your dictation.

1. Your full name: Richard M. Lister [Alias: J. Lister]
2. Your address: Box 366, Billy, Sask.
3. Date: January 1963
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Nacton, Essex, England
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Lionel Lister, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): July 1908
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: March 1902, Duncan River, Man.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.)
   Answer: 14 years old
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Answer: To homestead and find a better life
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Answer: I learned about the West through my uncle's stories who had emigrated many years before. We also read pamphlets about the West.
11. What did you friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They thought it was a good idea.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   All came as a party of three

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Bus and railway

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   Nothing outstanding

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   On a homestead with my uncle

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   On the East Belly district

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   No other place except for relocation in B.C. and settlement

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   I worked for my uncle in England
   I worked at farming
   I worked for the Government of Saskatchewan for the Department of Agriculture and the Department of Social Services
